column15: You don't want to think like that.
column16: All right.  But don't think like that because what the hell did we work for, Chris?  All of this, all of it, it's all just for you.
column17: I don't understand you, do I?

column2: He was out here when it broke.
column3: About four this morning.  I heard it crack and I looked out the window and he was standing right there when it cracked.
column4: I don't know.  But after he saw it, he ran back into the house and started crying in the kitchen.
column5: No.  I figured it was best to leave him alone.
column6: Yes, yes he is.  I don't know the meaning in it.  But I know one thing, mom, we made a terrible mistake with Dad.
column7: I don't want to argue with him.  But it's time that he knows that nobody else believes that Larry's alive. I mean
column8: Why shouldn't he dream about him, walk the nights waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say outright that we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for a long time?
column9: For Gods sake, three years!  Nobody comes back after three years.  It's insane!
column10: All right.  All right, just listen.
column11: You know it's not just my business.
column12: So it's all right then?  I should just go ahead with it?
column13: Isn't it your business, too, if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it?  You have such a talent for ignoring things.
column14: She's not Larry's girl.
column15: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something that I want, I have to pull back because it might hurt somebody else, my whole bloody life, time after time, after time.
column16: what to hell with that!
column17: I'll find out and then we'll thrash it out with dad, all right?  Mom, don't avoid me.
column18: So what, I'm not fast with women?
column19: Because it is.
column20: [garbage] I don't know.  It's just,

column2: Why does that bother you?
column3: She's been in New York three and a half years.  Why all of the sudden?
column4: What's going on here, Joe?
column5: She's not his girl.  She knows she's not.
column6: She's . . . Then why is she still single.  New York is full of men, why isn't she married?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she's waited.
column7: Because she knows what I know - she's faithful as a rock and my worst moments I think of her waiting and I know again that I'm right.
column8: Nobody in her- this house dares shake her faith.  Strangers might, but not his father, and not his brother.
column9: I want you to pretend like he's coming back!
column10: Because if he's not coming back, then I'll kill myself.
column11: Laugh.  Laugh at me, but what happens the night that she goes to sleep in his bed, and his memorial breaks in pieces?
column12: Only last week, another boy turned up in Detroit, been missing longer than Larry, you read it yourself.
column13: You've got to believe. You've got to--
column14: I can't help it!

column2: Why does that bother you?
column3: She's been in New York three and a half years.  Why all of the sudden?
column4: Well maybe.  Maybe she just wanted to see her again.
column5: What did you mean? He lived next door to the girl all of his life, why wouldn't he want to see her again? Don't look at me like that, he didn't tell me any more than he told you.
column6: How do you know he is even thinking about it?
column7: Well, so what.
column8: Now, listen, Kate, just-
column9: How do you know why she's waited?
column10: Look.  It's a nice day.  Why are we arguing?
column11: What do you want me to do? What do you want--
column12: But, Kate...
column13: [LAUGHTER]
column14: Calm yourself.
column15: Calm yourself!
column16: All right, all right.  Calm yourself.
column17: What do you mean me above all?  Look at you.  You're shaking!
column18: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

column2: I just got some bad news.
column3: My friend, Shotty, passed away.
column4: Oh, I'm so sorry
column5: The end, he's been sick for awhile.  He had cancer.
column6: Yeah.  It's just, I never thought it would actually happen, you know? I mean- He's such a fighter and he's always so positive about everything.
column7: You know, he was gonna, and we -- all the way up to the end we were just talking about how- you know all the stuff we were gonna do and, you know.  When he finally kicked this stupid cancer, you know, and we were gonna --
column8: he wanted to travel, you know.  And he's so talented.  Probably the most talented person I have ever met in my entire life.
column9: He was a designer, you know.  But he did everything. You know, He painted and he- and he did costume design, he did set design, he did lighting, he was --
column10: he just did everything.  He was literally, literally the most talented guy I have ever met in my entire life.
column11: And he's gone now and I  -- I just can't believe it.
column12: I mean, one second you think, you know, you're just having a conversation and then --
column13: you know, sometimes you think you want to make that phone call, or you think you want to tell somebody something, or something like that.  Do you know what I mean?  Like that's -- he was the person that I did that with.  You know, like, that's the person who I needed to call to tell things to all the time.
column14: And now I don't have that person anymore, you know.  And it's -- -- it's just, you.
column15: You think that things get easier, you know, as you as you get older and you -
column16: and it just gets worse.  It just gets worse, everything is bad all the time; people die, your friends die, family dies, your best friends die. it's-
column17: You always think, you know when you were- you know when you were a little kid and you think something is gonna happen, like, it will all be better when I am older, you know?
column18: No, you're right.  I don't.  You're right.
column19: Even, yeah -- he doesn't he would never feel that way, he would never want me to feel that way.  Of course not, but that's just where I am right now and -- -- I don't know what else to do with it.
column20: I just miss him.
column21: Thanks.

column2: Hi,um- I think my baggage was lost, and I need to I guess file a claim or I don't know what.
column3: Okay, what flight were you on?
column4: On what airline?
column5: From London, okay. Um- And you went through all your proper checkpoints?
column6: So you haven't seen your bags since Africa. You flew threw Heath Row to here.
column7: Okay.  Well, let me see here. I-
column8: It seems like it went through Heath Row.  I see it here. uh-
column9: But uh- I don't see it here in the airport yet. uh
column10: I'm not sure where it is.  We can absolutely keep an eye out for for it for you.
column11: Well, I'm not a miracle worker.  I don't know what I can do for you.  I don't have the bag right here.
column12: Well, as I told you, it left Heath Row and it seems to have arrived here.  But if you can't find it, then-are you sure you know what your bag looks like?
column13: Okay, and what is that?  What kind of bag is it?
column14: And you couldn't find it?
column15: Are you sure?
column16: Well, obviously, that wasn't me, so I'm going to have to ask you the same questions they asked you just so we can get to the same point.
column17: All right?  Now, um- it's green, travel bag, you couldn't find it.  And was there something important in it that you need it?
column18: Sentimental value.
column19: Right.  Well, I don't know what to tell you. Um- What I can offer you is a fifty dollar voucher on your next flight.
column20: No, I understand. I mean. It's got to be tough all those sentimental things, but um- this is all I can do for you.
column21: Well, you know, sometimes that's--really, I mean what else could we do?
column22: Well,
column23: Obviously ma'am.
column24: I am sorry, ma'am.
column25: Let's- Let's just relax for a moment, ma'am.  You understand, obviously, we're going to do everything we can to keep all of your luggage here.
column26: Obviously, we're not trying to lose your luggage.  Do you really believe that we're trying to lose your luggage ma'am?
column27: Well, we're talking about one bag.  You personally made it here, didn't you?
column28: That's what the cost of the ticket was for.
column29: Ma'am, international flights are not cheap and there's many reasons for that.  It does not have solely to do with your baggage or-
column30: Right. Yes, ma'am.
column31: Right, and also if you'll read the fine print of your agreement you'll see that while we do bear some responsibility for lost luggage, it is a fifty dollar voucher.
column32: Well, I understand that.  Did you buy flight insurance?
column33: Well, my hands are really tied then.
column34: Well, it's like any kind of insurance.  You don't-when you get it, then you get more. You know, Like if you--
column35: Well, of course not because you've got your backpack with you the whole time.  Now, if you--you said this was a travel bag.  Why weren't you carrying it on if it was so important?
column36: Uh, so it was really heavy.
column37: Well, you know what, it could still turn up, but until then I can offer you this fifty dollar voucher.
column38: I'm sorry, ma'am, there's nothing else I can do.  My hands are really tied here.  I really wish there was something else I could do for you.
column39: Well I don't know why you wouldn't believe that.
column40: Obviously, I'm doing everything that I can here.
column41: Well, I have no way to give you more money.  I'm giving you as much money as I can, and figuring- as far as figuring out where you bag is-
column43: The airline makes these rules, mom ma'am.
column44: Well, you can take my stinking fifty dollar voucher and go home and wait and see if your luggage turns up. And if it does, then we'll deliver it to you.
column45: I have no guarantee, absolutely not.
column46: How can I guarantee finding your luggage when it's lost?
column47: Right, well, when you're at home and you lose something, do you guarantee that you're going to find it later on?
column48: Well, it sounds to me like you're being ridiculous
column50: I understand that, ma'am, but things get lost.  There's nothing I can do about that.  Things happen.  Accidents happen.
column51: And while I really would love to be able to hand you your bag right now, obviously I can't do that.
column52: So you'd like the fifty dollar voucher?
column53: Okay, just fill out these three forms, and um- you'll- we'll have that sent to you within the next three weeks and, of course, we'll definitely keep an eye out for your bag.
